div.head: The Value of Prudence
div.p:
Have prudence: it is a great virtue. No doubt there
is a base prudence; - that which makes the mere senses the
ultimate tests of all value, ans which calls everything righteous
that happens to be gainful. But the true prudence is that
which, while it pays the just price of all its needs, will have full
value for every payment. And hence, in the long run, it must
gather into itself the best chances of success. In other words, it
must be greatly secure in a pecarious world - a world of profit and loss -
simply because its balance is perfect. And finally, if it is selfish, it is also
social; redeeming its own slips by a self recovery that is invulnerable,
and the slips of others by that sureness of council and help which converts
them into its clients

lg.l: Power's cheat, success but trying,
Even pleasure bears a sting;
Still 'tis useless - useless sighing -
Rather lisy to Hope replying:
"The Flowers will must come again with Spring!
And in the trampled way we're going
Streams of comfort yet are flowing -
Hark! I hear them murmuring."
Fame's a liar, state's invasion, *
Love too hath a wayward wing;
Still, hence seek not for occasion
To impugn Hope's sweet persuasion:
"That The Flowers will come again with Spring!"
And in the world-wide way we're going
Streams of pure good yet are flowing -
Hark! I hear them murmuring.
Friendship turns, itself denying,
Even truth the heart may wring;
Still, though trust be daily dying,
Listen still to Hope replying:
"The Flowers will come again with Spring!
And in the blasted way we're going
There's yet one healing current flowing -
Hark! I hear it murmuring."
All is dream-like, all off wingeth -
All that time and tide can bring!
Then cold Death his black pall bringeth -
Rest Still what matter while Hope singeth:
"Lo, Heaven is one eternal Spring!
And midway through it rolls a river
Wherein to bathe is joy health for ever -
Hark! I hear it murmuring."

note.p:
This expression was once objected to by an intelligent reader person to
whom the poem was read, as being too obviously sought for the rhyme's
sake only. But the expression had been well considered, and is true on all sides.
State, - whether a squireen's or a monarch's, - is emphatically invasion upon
our time, our means, our peace. First it is invasion in every way
upon the self disposal of clients, and then, through them, and
cumulatively, upon that of its individual centre. So much for
hasty criticism.

lg.l: I love him so,
That though his face I ne'er might see,
In the assurance that he so loved me,
This happy heart would glow
With pulses sweeter than the sweetest be
That colder ones can know.
I love him so,
That to my thought 'twere sweet to sleep
Even in death, believing he would keep,
With solemn step and slow,
In sabbath memory my gravem and weep
For her who slept below.
I love him so,
That all desires when he is by
Shrink even from the import of a sigh;
As flowers unseen that grow,
Being mute, must so remain; as in the sky
Are stars that none may know.
I see, as in a vision,
How face to face I stood
Long years ago with Dora,
In yon green wood:
Long years ago with Dora,
The gentle and the good -
The Angel of my destiny,
In yon green wood.
I said not that I loved her,
But well she understood
My bosom's beating secret
In yon green wood:
I dared not say I loved her,
Although I wished I could
Have told her so a thousand times,
In yon green wood.
The budding joys of fancy
Were like the maidenhood
Of morning blooms ungathered,
In yon green wood:
Of morning blooms ungathered,
While face to face we stood,
'Mid Hope's untrampled Eden both,
In yon green wood.
It saw affection's dawning,
And love's first purple mood,
And then two souls grow one soul,
Did yon green wood:
Alas! my heart is yearning,
Nor wonder that it should,
Since what hath been can be no more
In yon green wood.
As somewhat aye regretful
By destiny ensued,
For dreamers such as we were
In yon green wood,
Life to that heart hath spoken,
Though not with accent rude:
"Love's sweetest, wildest charm was left
In yon green wood."
A Huntress born to Nature
Through the might of olden lore,
Lithely on bounding,
Ere long lightens past me all there
Full like as the morning of
Hurry and vigor,
When I roam roaming the mountains o'er-
A Seer in soul, like a Poet of yore:
See her bow! - I see it plain,
And shafted quiver balanced nice!
See her robes, blown back amain,
Though looped in front with a sure device,
Sweeping behind her, like the train
Of a Bird of Paradise.
Or when the forest shadows
Are dew-silvered by the morn,
Lovely forth roaming,
Not long do I listen, tell
Suddenly sounding up,
Merry and mellow,
Hark! I hear to her mystic horn -

They glance, as past she boundeth there!
See her bow - a curve of light
Across her arm upraised and bare!

Or when the vales are sleeping

lg.l: The dulcimer was sounding
From within a mystic grove,
Where, strown with blooms, rose gleaming pure
A sculptured shrine of Love,
Round which tall Youths and Maidens fair
Went bounding in a row,
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Three thousand years ago.
And we, a group glad dancing
On this fair Australian earth,
Have met for the same Spirit here
To raise our rosy mirth;
To know it as those mouldered hearts
Did its sweet influence Know,
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Three thousand years ago
And in the days far coming
Upon Destiny's dim wing,
And aye her soul - her inward worth
Flushed out in subtle glows,
As from its heart came mantling forth
The ardors of a rose.
Of Cora with the snowy brow
Would mournful Memory sing:
Of how with Spring she came, and how
She left us with the Spring.
Her fairness only might be thought,
Or told if hearts could speak,
So subtle were the hues that wrought
Within her lucid cheek;
And with a many-branching charm
About her neck as well,
Went like the veins of light that warm
A lily of the dell.
But 'twas a glory from within
That made her front so fair -
A radiant spirit void of sin,
As working outward there.
Yea, like a veiling haze o'erflowed
With splendors of the moon,
Her soul's lit versture only showed
That soul how bright and boon!
Of Cora with the shining hair
Would mournful Memory sing;
Who came when flowers were everywhere,
And went, too, with the Spring.
Her locks, as they burnished, shone
In many a massy fold,
Or fell in their profusion down
Like bursting sheaves of gold.
Bright garments of a Spirit bright,
That even in the shroud,
Were like the sunset's aureate light
Within a lifeless cloud:
When she, our Angel of the Sun,
Had spread her wings in flight!
Alas, that weary day foregone!
That weary, weary night!
Of Cora yet, our lost delight,
Would mournful Memory sing;
Whose eyes at last grew such as might
Ne'er gladden out of Spring.
Those full orbed eyes of heaven-deep blue
Befringed with glossy jet,
So richly tender gentle - each a dew-
Illumined violet!
And for their fringe's ample dower
More sweetly rich they rayed,
As light within a shady bower
Is lovelier for the shade.
Though lovelier were they yet, in sooth,
For manifesting still,
Deep in their gentle depths, the truth
And beauty of her will.
But ah! Thou of the azure eyes
And shining golden hair,
Made'st what a void beneath the skies
Though flowers were everywhere,
When with the Spring we saw apart
Those eyes, those tresses curled;
And Summer, dying in Love's heart,
To Winter left the world!
Alas, our best beloved one!
Our heart's great lost delight!
Alas, that weary day foregone!
That weary, weary night!
Ah! Soul that wore the snowy brow
And gentle shining eyes,
Our song hath aye this burthen now
Beneath the vernal skies:
In vain the dews of heaven are shed
Where blight hath been before:
So vainly weep we o'er the Dead,
Yet only weep the more.
And they are ever most undone
Who best concieve delight,
For ev'n the Angels of the Sun!
Behind Leave after them leave - a the night!
Or from the bright time of her birth
And death, should Faith construe
How like the Spring, though not on earth,
Our joy shall bloom anew.2
There is no guage of worth
Or in fortune or in birth,
Nay, Kingly state is only
In itself a gilded rod;
But he who would not slight
For his life the cause of Right,
Or choose, to gain a star, the path
By splendid Evil trod,
Though he lack the power of gold,
And his robe be worn and old,
He - he is the true Noble -
The Gentleman of God.
A man may live in state
With the wealthy and the great,
He may mingle with the gifted
And muster with the brave;
But if he acts a part
Unapproved by his own heart,
Or takes, though from a Monarch's hand,
What justice never gave;
Or is numbered with the throng
Who uphold a throned Wrong, -
He's a coward and a trailor,
A liar and a slave!
We know that man is prone
To bow down to Power alone,
Or right or wrong, for Earth's glooms
Will cloud an earthy wit;
But in his heart, though dark,
There yet glows one truthful spark -
The Kin-spark of the Angel, whose
First brightness grows from it;
And so be he never swerve
From whate'er its light would serve,
On his high throne of Manhood
A sun-born God might sit.
Then let the truth be known
Unto all, in every zone,
That kingly state is only
In itself a gilded rod;
That he who acts a part
Unapproved by his own heart,
With villain foot is treading where
True honor never trod!
While in him - the lowliest wight
Who is constant to the right,
There stands a very Noble -
A Gentleman of God.
Where Beauty is smiling
With love undenied,
And gladness is flowing
From Pleasure's hill side -
Whatever of charming,
Thus absent, I see,
I can turn from it, Mary,
To think upon thee.
When blasts of affliction
Blow cold on my rest,
And the pang that will sleep not
Is loud in my breast;
Still, however clinging
These troubles may be,
I can turn from them, Mary,
To think upon thee.
When Weariness sleepeth,
And Care is at rest;
When Happiness dreameth
Of all it loves best;
Then as the Moon gazes
Entranced on the sea,
My soul, o'er thy dwelling,
Dreams down upon thee.
When broad o'er her hill-top
Hangs Eve's glowing star,
Comes A spirit of beauty comes,
As of from afar;
To dream through the gloaming's
Heart-hushing degrees,
And breathe like a vow
In the odour-sweet breeze:

lg.l: To mellow the echoes
That bleat from the hills
Where the Shepherds are folding
Their flocks by the rills;
In the wild woods to deepen
The dove's gentle voice -
To live in all life,
In all gladness rejoice.
It is breathing around,
It is glowing above,
That spirit of beauty -
The Spirit of Love.
Sir Gilbert is a happy Knight,
And happier is he aye,
To think his sole Child's lovesome eyes
Grow lovelier day by day:
Two violets bathed in morning dew,

lg.l: Two well-springs hued filled with heaven, as though
Their willowy fingers seen! shown
And so it hath been ever forth
Since first his heart could say:
A Lily of the Love's green Valley
Is born to me this day.
Sir Gilbert is a gladsome man -
A gladsome and a free. *
But why hath he provoked to day
This storm of minstrelsy?
It is as though his heart had run
Stag-wild with mirth and wit,
And he would have old Time's grey one
Go bounding on with it!
But did you ask the reason why,
The happy man would say:
My Lily of the green Valley
Is seven years old to day.
Sir Gilbert was a gladsome man -
A gladsome and a free;
But silent in his hall is now
The voice of minstrelsy:
It may be, he hath felt his prime
A-wearing from him fast
And so would use the coming time
More staidly than the past.
But did you ask the reason why,
The altered man would say:
My Lily of the Love's green Valley
Is withering fast away.

div.l: Sir Gilbert was a stalwart Knight,
And sturdy as a tree,
Though genial as the warmth of wine
In pleasant company;
And can it be, that he hath so
Misused a year of time,
That few his face again would know
Who saw him in his prime?
Ah! that is not the reason why
His head is turned so grey:
His Lily of the Love's dimm' blanched Valley
Has withered all away.

div.head: A Dream of the Orient. X

lg.l: With a splendid Eastern bride
Like a houri at my side,
And music round us swelling
'Mid odours of so rare a stream
That unembodied souls they seem,
Dwell I, through a radiant dream,
In a rich Orient dwelling.

l.add: On wreathen pillar slender
And in their recesses - lo,
Clouds of purple hangings glow
In such semblances as show
A summer sunset's sunset's wondrous splendor

lg.l: Near a fountain flashing high
In the pleasure-court we lie,
Each on a gorgeous pillow:
The columned water, mounting, breaks
In outward curves and falling flakes,
Till the whole a picture makes
As of a crystal willow.
And fair faces, darkly bright,
Like the countenance of Night
Seen in her starry glory
All ministrant around us throng
And breathes their pathos into song,
Or in words, as rich, prolong
Some wild rich-worded story.
Till through many voices, one
Like a gush of gold doth run:
"Why - why should kindred sever?
Our life is a perpetual feast
Of being, from all care released,
Sunny souls are for the East -
Then dwell with us for ever!"
It was, I well remember,
The merry Springtime, when
Young Dora in the eventide
Came singing up the Glen:
Came singing up the Glen
Till the warble of her stream, one many-warbled park
Like a subtle stream of vocal fire,
Ran glowing through my brain. heart
A fond resolve, long cherished,
Till now then I might control;
Till now then - but oh! that witching strain
It drew it from my soul:
It drew it from my soul,
And she did not say me nay,
And the world of Love was all the world
To us that happy day.
I'm happy now in thinking
How happy I was then,
When tow'rds the glowing west my love
Went homeward down the Glen:
Whent homeward down the Glen,
While my comfort surer grew,
Till methought the old-faced hills all looked
As they were happy too.
All happy, for that Dora
And I so happy were;
All happy, for that Human Love
Had breathed its spirit there:
Had breathed its spirit there,
And had made them conscious grow
Of the part they bore in that sweet time -
That happy Long Ago.

lg.l: Heaven's face was starred as now,
When homeward, long ago, I trod:
Blest! - having won my Dora's vow
To love me next to God!
And as homeward then I went
Upon that happy far night,
Up into the firmanment
My glowing spirit rayed, and lent
Even to the star-light.
Years are gone - and Dora now
Is gone, too, under the green sod:
No! - gone to Paradise with her vow
To love me next to God!
And as here aloft I gaze
As on that happy far night,
Heaven's face is all a-blaze,
And up my spirit, yearning, rays -
But above the star-light.

div.head: The Wrath of Love. not copied in manuscript

lg.l: To have the heart mispread by one
Who is alone Love-throned there,
Evokes a bitterness that none
May utter for despair.
Till anger brings a fierce relief,
And then our words flash forth amain -
The lightnings of a stormy grief
That thunders in the brain.
But soon this tempest of the mind
Is hushed away by pleading fears;
And if it leaves a cloud behind,
That cloud dissolves in tears.

div.head:
not in manuscript
Falling Away. X

lg.l: The wintry wind is numbing,
When blowing keen and high,
It hunts the dull and drizzling clouds
Across the rayless sky;
But ah! how much more chilling
Is it when, on Friendship's death,
Some old acquaintance meets us with
A coldness in his breath.
It is cheerless - very cheerless
To miss some well known site, doom dome
Because the golden day light is quenched
In damp and darksome night; timeless night's gloom
But ah! yet more disheart'ning
Is it when, we know not why,
Some old acquaintance fronts us with
A strangeness in his eye.
It is not that we're losers
Of aught the sordid prize;
And scorn breeds scorn, and Memory, wronged,
With teach us to despise:
But oh! the waste of heart-faith,
When to Friendship's cold disgrace,
Some old acquaintance meets us with
A frost upon his face.
Hold to the right, and be loyal in all things:
This is of Manhood the only true plan!
Hold to thy faith, or in great or in small things:
This is the statute God layeth on Man!
Build not thy structures upon the world's notion,
Deeming all good may be compassed with pelf;
Nothing in fortune in worth thy devotion -
Nothing's worth loving that owns not itself.
Perish the wisdom that makes us time-servers!
Perish the virtue that's gain in disguise!
Leave them to cowards, to seemers and swervers,
Yea, make them the scorn of the valiant and wise!
Fear not when wrong power contriveth undue laws
That right shall flow pure through the peoples no more!
Blench not when traitors abandon a true cause -
For the truth of it liveth with God as before!
Nations benighted by failure, believe not;
But wait for the morning, do thou, - and believe:
Mammon's high castles ban the poor, and relieve not;
But make God thy debtor, do thou, - and relieve.
Live - die for thy own (be they many or few men,)
Following love even into the grave!
Thus, and thus only, can any be true men,
Faithful in all things, and pious, and brave.

div.head:
George Washington. not in manuscript
W.H.

lg.l: Even as the one sole star of morning
Shines that Name upon the earth!
Even as a God-lit light adorning
A great Nation's clouded birth!
Or like an altar-flame it rises
From the field of Freedom's battle won:
Then send it out, - o'er the whole wide world;
That patriot name - George Washington.
To breathe it, is to brand all trading
With Through dominion for a throne;
To know it, is to curse all wading
Into blood for power alone!
While like an altar flame it rises
From the fields of Freedom's battles won:
Then send it out, - o'er the whole wide world;
That stainless name - George Washington.
No cry is it for frantic glory
Such as sworded hirelings land;
No greatness is there in its story
Or of conquest or of fraud!
But like an altar-flame it rises
From the fields of Freedom's battles won:
Then send it out, - o'er the whole wide world;
That sacred name - George Washington.

div.head:
A Royal The Child of Destiny. Not in manuscript
W.H

lg.l: If never by the arms of reason
Truth's last battle may be won,
But aye the work of mutual slaughter
Men must do, as men have done,
For Class, for Faction, or for One:
Then, - still to keep the road of progress,
Let our chosen Leader be
Some bold and matchless Freedom-queller -
Some self-raised, self-crowned man-compeller,
In whom 'twere folly base weak then not to see
A royal Child of Destiny.
And if we cannot quit with Monarachs, Tyrants
But by doom must subjects vassals be;
Nor bundle, once for all, to heaven,
Or to hell - elsewhere, that false degree
Heraldic aristocracy!
Then, - still to keep one right road open,
Let us turn, and bend the bend at once our knee
To some unparagoned Freedom-queller -
Some self-raised, self-crowned man-compeller,
In whom 'twere folly base weak then not to see
A royal Child of Destiny.
Never give up: though Life be a battle
Wherein true men may fall and true causes be sold,
Yet, on the whole, - however may rattle
The thunders of Chance, searing cowards like cattle, -
True Clear Victory's alway the bride of the bold.
Armed in your right: though Friendship deny you,
And Love fall away when the storm's at the worst;
Count not your loss, - 'twas destined, to try you, -
Bear the brunt like a man, and your deeds shall ally you
To natures more noble and true than the first.
Rail not at Fate: if truly you scan her
There's none loves more strongly the heart that endures:
On, in the old Macedonian a Hero's self-sanctioning manner,
With the strength of your soul held aloft like a banner,
And the day, if you do but live through it, is yours.
Be this your faith: till poured out like water
Is the wealth sweat of your will, where your efforts have died:
Be it your faith, - till killing stroked clatter
On your harness, and then - there's an end of the matter -
A brave end of the matter, if nothing beside.
I envy no greatness, I bow to no pride,
I am lord of what none can be lord of beside,
Though, lonely and landless, I dwell in no more
Than a Lodge where the wild wood hangs shadowing o'er.
And Love, if heroic, right healthful and strong,
Like the passion whose amaranth bloometh in song,
As bees hive their honey its sweetness might store
In a Lodge where the wild wood hangs shadowing o'er.
And a Poet , like Shakespear, the heart-seer prfound,
Or like Milton whose genius but heaven could bound,
Might build up his judgment and chasten his lore
In a Lodge where the wild wood hangs shadowing o'er.
For where there's a free heart, blood royal is there,
And true love's a honey bee everywhere;
While the Muse never heeds how we house what she gives,
Since no Dwelling is mean where a thorough man lives!
Oh, Love is passing sweet,
When we meet
With a golden-hearted Maid,
Not afraid
To indrink its Orphic fire,
Till her whole soul, like a lyre,
Thrill and beat
To the thought, and with the feeling, -
Love is sweet.
'Tis like a sunset sky
To the eye;
It is like an odorous wind
To the mind;
It is like the fervent roll
Of rich music to the soul -
And we cry
Let us always love, or failing, -
Let us die!
Wrongly she loveth, doth true-hearted Carry,
Loving a vagrant, her kindred aver!
But all gone adrift must her faith be ere Harry -
Wild Harry the rover's a vagrant to her.
Oft doth the wayward one make her feel lonely,
Wilding away like a wave of the main;
But she knows that he loves her , and loveth her only,
And so she forgives him again and again.
Quick come the glad day - Oh! were it to-morrow,
When in Love's haven her wild one shall rest!
But living or dying, in joy or in sorrow,
She'll love him as now - and in loving do best.
So must it fortune, since tried love, unwasted,
Meriteth heaven on heaven's own plan:
And so must it fortune, since tried faith, unblasted,
Is ever the germ of the angel in man.

div.head:
not in manuscript
W.H Old Billowy Hawksb'ry. X

lg.l: Old billowy Hawksb'ry, so bravely expanding,
The same as of old, as abounding and free!
Alas, for that lone One beside thee now standing,
How failure hath shrunk him since last he saw thee!
Then was glassed in thy blue depth, untouch'd by To-morrow,
A vision-lit face with no hint of a furrow,
But the fire-coutter'd plough of a wanderer's sorrow
Hath passed o'er his brow since he saw thee before.
And what did the Maiden he strayed by thy side with?
She wedded another when darkened his day!
And what of the Schoolmates he bathed in thy tide with?
They, too, have forgot him, or wandered away!
Yet, as shells seem intoned by breathe the tone of their once native ocean,
Is How the life of the Past not a seems to stir in thy motion,
Recalling a sense of the his youthful devotion
He dreamt Beauty To beauty and friendship, when near thee before?
But in vain doth to forget doth that lone one endeavour,
The alienate Home of his father of yore,
So better to him was the task, thou bright river,
To feel like a stranger in passing its door;
While he thought of fond words that within it had sounded,
From parents, with, welcoming, surrounded, welcoming parents, as tow'rds them he bounded,
And With a brother that now in yon churchyard lies mounded
Side by side with his sire, - since he saw thee before.
And alas! for the days that are gone, he cried , lowly,
With all that they yielded, and promised as well!
Since feelings and hopes that once made you roof holy,
Have now such a mourful home-story to tell!
Then he plucked from a tree he had planted a blossom,
And laid it to die, like a child, in his bosom,
His eyes ached - and lo, he hath come to repose 'em
On something unchanged since he saw thee before.

div.head:
not in Copied in manuscript
W.H The Forgotten.

lg.l: He shone in the senate, the camp, and the grove,
The mirror of manhood - the darling of love.
He fought for his Country, - the star of the brave,
And died for its weal when to die was to save.
And Wisdom and Valor long over him wept,
And Beauty, for ages, strewed flowers where he slept.
And the Bards of his people inwrought with their lays
The light of his glory and truth of his praise.
But afar in the foreworld have faded their strains,
And now of his being what record remains?
Within a lone valley a Tomb crumbles fast,
The name of whose Sleeper is lost in the past.

l.del: Trust and treachery, wisdom, folly,
Madness, mirth, and melancholy,
Love and hatred, thrift and pillage,
All are housed in one small village.
And if in such the a world's mixed being,
Where may Peace from ruin fleeing
Find fit shelter, and inherit
All the calm of her own merit?
In a bark of gentle motion
Sailing on the summer ocean?
- There worst war the tempest wages,
And the hungry whirlpool rages!
In some lonely new-world bower
Hidden like a forest flower?
- There, too, - there, to fray the stranger,
Stalks the wild-eyed spirit Danger!
In some Alpine Cot, by fountains
Flowing from snow-shining mountains?
- There the avalanches thunder,
Crunching all that lieth under!
In some hermit-cell, pitched lowly
'Mid the tombs of prophets holy?
- There, to harry and annoy her,
Roams the infidel distroyer!
In great palace chambers gilded,
Guarded round with tombs high builded?
- Change may enter these to-morrow,
And, with Change, - a peerless sorrow!
Vainly would she thrive by roving
Over wide unpeopled spaces,
Or in wide and virgin places,
Or in hoping, or in loving,
Where throned Power is girt with legions;
Having Or in wild in all regions, -
Or in
Vainly would she thrive by roving
Over wild unpeopled spaces,
Or in wild and virgin places,
Or in hoping, or in loving,
Where throned Power is girt with legions;
Having Having, whether still or moving in all times and in all regions, -
Or in none, - a home of beauty
In the fearless heart of Duty;
Dwelling there with Truth, and viewing
God through all things - all renewing.

lg.l: Do you dream of the future, my Boy?
That future is dreaming of you!
Summery seasons so heart-full of joy,
Drear Wintery periods too:
All thronged with shadowy hopes and fears,
All streaked with smiles and gleamed with tears,
The sweet and bitter of coming years:
Dream you of these? These of you
In the spirit of fortune are all dreaming too.
Or comes to your slumber some thought
Of your mystical life in the Past,
Like a far-wasting reaching melody caught
As Out of a pause in Time's blast -
A thought of loving ones afar
Who blest you in some other Star,
That rolleth through heaven its golden car?
Love them again! Just as fast
As Time flyeth, the present becometh the past.
For Nay, the Present, the Past, the To-come,
Are nothing, sweet dreamer, I see,
But Time's three-in-one, since Being's their home -
That Being that which ever must be!
Whence thou, - I, - all, - our stand have each
Where never but in seeming ever reach
The wild surge waves breaking on Death's dark beach!
Dreaming we or dead - are not we with all three,

l.del: Even now and for evermore with them all three?
Thro' the Once having been once, we for ever shall have.
Having

l.add: Through the fact our having been, ever are we!
In virtue of having been, ever are we!
with all three
In spirit our essence (once having been being) for ever are we!

div.head:
not in manuscript
W.H
The Tree of Liberty.

lg.l: We'll plant a Tree of Liberty
In the centre of the Land,
And round it ranged as guardians, no ranging, fierce and free,
A wall of men will heroes stand;
And sages bold and mighty-souled
Shall dress it day by day:
But woe be to the tractor recreant who
Would break one branch away.
Then sing the Tree of Liberty
For the boast that we have made;
May it so flourish that when we
Are buried in its shade,
Fair Womanhood and Love and Good
All pilgrims pure shall go ,
Its growth to bless for happiness -
Oh may it flourish so!
Till felled by gold as Bards have told,
In the Old World once it grew,
Though there its fruits were always sold,
And only to the Few:
But here at last, uncursed by caste,
Each man at nature's call,
Shall pluck as well what none may sell -
The fruit that blooms for All!
By gold 'twas felled, as Bards have held,
In the Old World long ago,
But here what there its life dispelled
In with its sap shall flow:
The evil bout of Time is out,
And gold no more a thrall,
Shall here but build for Truth, and gild
The fruit that blooms for All.
Then sing the Tree of Liberty,
And the men who shall defend
Its glorious future faithfully
For this so righteous end:
That happiness all men to bless
Out with its growth may grow -
Our Southern Tree of Liberty
Shall flourish even so.

div.head:
not in manuscript
Speak the Truth.

lg.l: Let the truth be always told,
Despite of loss, or bonds, or death!
It fits not that the bold
Should breathe dishonest breath.
Truth in word is first the way
For all who would in deed be true:
And none should dare dare fear to say
What he would will to do.
'Tis the sole heroic plan -
The one strict line 'twixt low and high!
For it unmans a Man
Only to think a lie.

div.head:
not in manuscript W.H
This Southern Land of Ours.

lg.l: With clowns to make our laws, and knaves
To rule us , as of old,
In vain our soil is rich, in vain
'Tis seamed with virgin gold!
But the present only yields us nought,
The future only lours,
Till we have a finer braver Manhood
In this Southern Land of ours.
What would pygmean statesmen but
But Our new-world prospects blast,
In By chaining Enterprise and Thought
To the misyielding past;
With all its misery for the mass,
And fraud-upholden powers:
But we'll have a purer Manhood larger braver system
In this Southern Land of ours!
And lo, the unploughed Future, boys!
May yet be all our own,
If hearts that love their Native Land Soil
Determine, [this alone]: (every one,)
To sow its years for crops of truth,
And border these with flowers,
Whom Till we have a nobler Manhood
In this Southern Land of ours.

div.head:
Forward Ho! not copied in manuscript
W H

lg.l: Forward ho! forward ho! Soldiers of Liberty!
Hope on Right on! Hope; fight on! till Man's whole race shall be
Free of all good under heaven's wide dome!
And doubt not, the Earth that has grown old in sorrow,
Shall grow young again in the light of that morrow
Predestined to make her Fraternity's home.
Forward ho! forward ho! Lovers of truth and good!
Think on; write on; till the Earth's whole herohood
Stand in one faith under heaven's wide dome;
And shout to behold all the hill-tops adorning
With sun-flowers of glory, the glow of that morning
Predestined to seal her Fraternity's home.

div.head:
Never Mind. not in manuscript
W.H.

lg.l: My Country, though rude yet, and wild, be thy nature,
This alone our proved love should begat and command ,:
That There's room in thy broad breast for Manhood's full stature,
And that Honest Endeavour's a lord in the land.
And though much of thy bounty, by aliens in feeling
Has been made upon heads the least worthy to fall,
Their reign is nigh past, and the wrong is fast healing,
And thy wide arms encircle a home for us all.
And though pygmies high placed in our councils yet fool us,
In our woods there's a Giant upgrowing the while -
The Spirit of Liberty destined to rule us,
And cheer on the world from the world from the great Austral Isle!

div.head:
not copied in manuscript
W.H
The Emigrant's Vision.

lg.l: As our Bark dashed away o'er the night shrouded deep,
And out towards the South I was gazing,
First there passed o'er my spirit a darkness like sleep,
Then the light of a Vision amazing!
As rises the Moon, from the white waves a far
Came a Goddess it seemed of love wisdom and war,
And on her bright helmet, encircling a star,
Behold there was graven "Australia".
Her robes were as green as the mantle of Spring
Newly spread by the streams that so mildly
Elapse through yon flock-dappled plains, or that sing
'Mid those blue-ranging mountains so wildly:
Her locks were as bright as the lustre that lies
At morn on the seas of the South, and her eyes
Were as deep in their joy as the clear sunny skies -
The clear sunny skies of Australia.
O Stranger, she asked, hast thou fled from the home
Which thy forefathers bled for so vainly!
Does shame for its past thus induce thee to roam,
Or despair of its future constrain thee?
In the far sunny South there's a refuge from wrong,
Where the Shiloh of Freedom, expected so long,
Through genius already hath shouted his song:
'Tis the evergreen land of Australia.
There Truth her abode on the forest-clad hills
Shall establish - a dweller for ever;
And Plenty rejoice by the gold-pebbled rills,
Aye wedded to honest Endeavour:
Till the future a numberless people shall see
All equally noble as equally free,
And the God they adore their sole monarch shall be!
Then come, build thy home in Australia.
This said, tow'rds the South she passed brightly away,
And at once as from slumber I started;
But the cadences sweet of its welcoming lay
Yet breathed of the Vision departed.
And when o'er the deep these had fadingly spread,
The swell of my heart as it rose to my head
Broke loud into words on my tongue - and I said
Be the home of my hope then Australia!
The only faithless thing is Man,
Whose evil plan
Excludes Man's brotherhood:
All else are trusty to the rod
And sireship of Almighty God,
But Man in 'his lordly mood.
The honest Moon pays down her light
In silver bright;
The Sun in burning gold;
The stars above the hills that rise
Like thought-informed and earnest eyes,
Keep compact as of old.
The birds their pristine glees prolong -
The flowery throng
Bloom as they bloomed alway;
The beasts amid the fields that won
Are loyal to their mould as on
Creation's earliest day.
'Tis Man alone - dishonest Man,
Who schemed a plan
Excluding brotherhood!
He only, with disnatured mind,
Becomes the savage tyrant of his kind:
He! in his lordly mood.

l.del: 'Tis Man - 'tis recreant Man alone
Who builds a Throne
And makes it his belief!
[Who preaches meekly - chiefly meekness - surelier to betray!]
Who teaches - to enslave or slay!
Who joys - at others' grief!

lg.l: But shall there not be yet a time,
When this stern rhyme
Shall be no longer true?
When Man shall re-create the mood
That guileless kept the brotherhood
He erst in Eden knew?
There shall! The very dream that we
Might faithful be,
Assures us that there shall!
When Freedom, to her mission true,
Shall commonise the all-grasping true,
So to ennoble all.
Be loyal yourself, if you'd prove
All the nearness and worth of your mate;
For whatever damages love
Is making an inroad for laying you open to making an inroad for hate.
Be true to your own to the end,
And to comfort them never be slow;
For whatever weakens a your a friend
Must strengthen on your in somewise a your a foe.
Be prim to your Faith; 'tis a rod
Of support in the weariest way:
And the life-path that leads you from God,
What can it but lead you astray?

l.del: What now in all the world might move
My wearied being to the core,
As once could love - that morning love
Which I, alas! may feel no more;
When Dora, fonder for the theft,
In haste would meet me - soon to part
With backward looks that ray-like left
Their glances in my heart.
Her presence made all nature bright,
And all within, as all without;
Or absent, she was one delight
To dream ten thousand things about!
Alike to me in shine or shower
The day and night away might roll,

lg.l: While the sweey spirit of her power
Was reigning in my soul.
Ah, what in all the world might move
My wearied being to the core,
As could that love - the morning love
Which I, alas! may feel no more?
The mountain measure of its might -
Its joy so ocean-like and vast,
Can now be but a thought delight -
A Vision of the past!

l.add:
Cancelled in
this place

lg.l: One Summer evening passed beside yon river
Hath lost its sunset in my soul for ever:
Passed by yon river's side
With one who should have been my happy bride -
My happy, happy bride!
But Earth's dark doom for aye denies
All chance of another Paradise!
The mouth I pressed then, like a bee-broached blossom,
As with new honey seemed to fill my bosom:
Those magical sweet lips,
They thrilled me even to the finger tips -
Those precious, precious lips!
But ah! how much of joy may be,
At length, but a sigh of Memory!
And onward, even as the stream was flowing,
That sweet time hurried with its sunset glowing:
And she is far away
Who blest my being on that happy day -
Gone from me far away!
And all Love hoped is now, at last,
Like that rich eve - but a rich dream past!
Ah many Many and many a day is gone hath flown
Since face to face were stood we,
Gramachree!
Under the shadowy Wild-fig Tree;
While the suns of the past went cloudless down in the red west shone;
And yet how my distant heart is thrilled
Like a leap that is swept by the breeze alone,
Whenever I'm think thinking of thee,
Gramachree!
And my head with a dim wild stir is filled,
Like the sound remote of a sooming sea.
'Tis a sense of fond feeling of happier days,
(When face to face were we,
Gramachree!
Under the shadowy Wild-fig Tree,
Close hid from the low sun's cloudless lengthening rays)
That thrills and sweetens within my breast
Like a breeze that afar from its Eden strays,
Whenever I think I'm thinking of thee,
Gramachree!
And this dim brain-stir is the wild unrest
Of a moaning and homeless memory.
Ah, that the beautiful Spirit of Love,
That when a-met were we,
Gramachree!
Under the shadowy Wild-fig Tree,
Then sat as it were in the boughs branches above,
Impassioning all our sympathies,
Should be wandering now like the arkless dove -
Or only once have been only to be,
Gramachree!
Thus re-felt in the stir of Thought's mystic breeze,
And the shell-like murmurs of Memory!

div.head: The Girl Maiden. I left behind me.

lg.l: I wandered east, I wandered west,
For long years, hoping yearly
That fortune at last would give me rest
With the One I loved most dearly:
Hoping ever it might be so,
As the spirit of fancy inclined me,
So purely my heart's queen long, long ago
Was the Girl MaidenI left behind me.
To wander aye would seem my lot,
To wander aye, though weary;
Striving in vain to compass what
My spirit hath prized most dearly:
No longer I deem it may be so,
For fancy no longer can blind me -
Ah, well-a-day for the long, long ago,
And the Girl I left behind me!
It may be, had we mated been,
And I had never wandered,
The Eden of Love ere this had seen
Its beauty and bloom all squandered!
But Oh! in my heart, a vacant ake
At thought of the past will remind me
How lonely it is for the sad sweet sake
Of the Girl I left behind me.
Words are the special dies of Thought,
And well they coin its gold;
But Feeling cannot so be brought
Within their subtlest mould.
With minds on some great theme intent,
We seek to them at length,
And lo, we utter all we meant,
To wonder at their strength!
But when we through their might would wreak
The expression, hardly sane,
Of highest joy, or grief, - how weak
We find them, and how vain!
Acting the bliss of feeling, Thought
May catch siege her very air,
And then, as to her heaven up-caught,
Its transports thus declare:
My joy floods out, like Horeb's rill
Loosed by the Prophet's rod!
My soul, all light, with blissful will
Rays like a star of God!
But Feeling's happy self, the while,
All silently apart,
May only wear a glowing smile,
And breathe as from the heart.
Or Thought, to imitate her woe,
May wildly cry aloud,
My peace is wasting as I go,
Even like a summer cloud!
My spirit hath so deep a wound,
No cure might be designed devised,
And shed like water on the ground
Is all my soul hath prized!
While Feeling's self may only shake
Her woeful head, and or start
To find how vainly words would break
The silence of her heart.
But most when Music's fire seraph fire
Comes kindling through the air,
Making it such as Gods respire,
(And Gods perhaps are there!)
How vainly would the subtlest wit
Word-picture as they roll
The clouds of glory it hath lit
Like sunrise in the soul!
Like sunrise, when its conquering glow
Smites through the vapours cold,
Till all their ragged chasms gorges flow
With floods of burning gold!

l.add: Or when that holiest spirit, Love,
Plumed with parpurial beams,
Comes like a heaven-descended dove,
To nestle with our dreams;

lg.l: The deep of the Ineffable -
A Deep that none may sound,
Pours round us with its breathing spell -
Immeasurably round!

l.add: In vain would Thought , in words, though rich
Can Though And rare as gems, reveal,
That mystic grace of passion, which
We feel - and only feel!

div.head: The Scenic Part of Poetry. X

lg.l: What's Poetic? I ask, if a green wood is not, -
A green wood by balmy winds stirred;
And a runnel that slides with a flash from its grot,
And a trill like the song of a bird:
And we prize them, when pictured by Poesy, more
Than we did when old outlying things,
Because they are brought as it were to our door
Through the spell that around us she flings.
What's Poetic? I ask, if a sunset is not,
When it turns all the depths of the west
Into jasper seas rolled round some pearl-mountained diamond cragged spot,
Or some purple cloud-isle of the blest:
And we prize it, when pictured by Poesy, more
Than we did when to Nature confined,
Because ever never thenceforth it glows at our door it is fixed, as a store, as of yore can
In the scenic world-dome of the mind.
What's Poetic? I ask, if a tempest is not,
With its dragon-winds billowing by,
And its thunder-flames suddenly showing, red jagging out hissingly hot,
As through fractures and flaws in the sky:
And we prize it, when pictured by Poesy, more
Than we did when while its terror was known,
Because its dread face then looks in at our door
In the strength of its grandeur alone.
What's Poetic? I ask, if some Hecla is not,
Standing grim in a wild winter-world,
With its lava-floods seething from chasm and grot,
And its fire-rocks at heaven up hurled:
And we prize it, when pictured by Poesy, more
Than we did should in the outward alone,
Because it shall ever thence agonise at our door not and roar in our lore
As a wonder- raised birth of her own.
What's Poetic? I ask, if the ocean is not,
Or in storm, or when plain-like it sleeps,
Lying wide as the heaven whose face is begot
Again in the womb of its deeps:
And we prize it, when pictured by Poesy, more
Than we did while around us it wrought,
Because ever thenceforth it lies at our door it is then, not as , as before,
As But a mighty possession of thought.
Why smile you, as in sweet amaze,
My Mary, - Mary mine, to see
These olden things in Nature's ways
So full of joy pleasure-full for me?
For if I cannot well command
My joy in aught of glorious frame,
Though common, - beautiful or grand,
Thy influence is to blame!

l.add: And also in its shade it was
That first I dared my love to tell:
And this, I say, is the because
Of its [erotic] Muse mystic memorial Muse semblant spell

lg.l: Here gazing at those evening skies,
I'm soul-bathed bathe as in in their starry blue,
Because I know thy loving eyes
Are glorying in it too.
And more, 'tis simply thence, I guess,
It seems too in itself so glad,
And touched as wirh lovingness
It one time never had.
And aye how fondly can I trace
Yon shining River's winding stream,
For having seen it glass thy face
As in a happy dream.
Nor wonder, Mary, it should thence
In With that fond passion mix and roll,
The fountain of whose profluence
Lies deepest in my soul.
And why for ever in my view
So Muse-like looks the wild-fig tree?
- 'Twas in its shade that first I knew
To rhyme sweet thoughts of thee.

l.add: Lies deepest in my soul, indeed,
And under its ideal skies,
Doth flow in melody, and feed
Its flowers of Paradise

lg.l: And bending o'er this virgin rose,
What sweetness is there at my heart,
To think its sister-likeness shows
Thy Floral counterpart.
Nay, more; - to me seems any flower
Itself with actual feeling warm,
Because some influence of thy power
Hath passed into its form.
For Love is God's flower, Mary mine,
And nature, tending up to God,
Treads on the skirts of the divine,
1850 Wherever Love hath trod.

div.head: Finally copied The Hunter's Indian Dove. X

lg.l: Dark is her cheek, but her blood's rich blush
Comes through its dusk with a sunset flush,
While Joy, like a prairie-bee, slaketh its drouth
At the red hony-cup * of her smiling mouth,
And her wild eyes glance like planet stars rare
'Neath the streaming storm of her night-black hair.
And ever I pride in my Forest choice
The more while I list to her bird-like voice,
Warbling old songs in her own wild speech,
But aye with this new refrain to each:
Who'll pity - who'll comfort the dark-plumed dove,
When the white hawk leaves her to die of love?

note.p:
In allusion to the red-cup - a flower (or rather the
flower) of the American Prairies.

lg.l: O then, by the artless tears that rise
'Neath the downcast lids of her gleaming eyes, -
By the truthfully tender and touching grace
That boding passion then lends her face,
I swear in the very wild spirit of love
Never to part from my Indian Dove!
A little light, heat, motion, breath -
Then silence, darkness, and decay,
Are all that difference Life and Death
In him who weareth clay:
But Time's one drop 'twixt that and this,
Ah! what a grief of doom it is!
The cheek is fair, the eye is bold,
The ripe lip like a berry red:
Then the shroud clothes them: - thus behold
The Living and the Dead!
And how Time's last cold drop serene
Swells to eternity between!
But Yet not for horror, nor to weep,
But through the solemn dark to see
That Life, though swift, is wonder-deep,
And Death the only key
That Which lets to that mysterious height
Where Earth and Heaven in God unite.
This [world] life Man's life is but a boastful weakness,
Pale with terrors unconfessed;
Yet Virtue may not lose her treasurer,
And God is power exceeding measure: -
Wherefore all is for the best.

l.add: In the end -
In that certain Godward end
Tow'rds which all things, working, tend.

lg.l: The world is mountained o'er with [trouble, ] failure danger
And with danger failure and unrest:
Yet all things tend to is it isled in the supernal,
And God is peace - yea, peace eternal: -
Wherefore all is for the best.

l.add: In the end - &c

lg.l: The world is clouded up with error,
And with folly unridressed:
Yet even wise men are forecasting,
And God is wisdom everlasting: -
Wherefore all is for the best.
The world is sowed with lies for lucre -
Lies that every heart infest:
Yet Fraud is overcome by Duty,
And God's is truth, and truth is beauty: -
Wherefore all is for the best.
Power, peace, wisdom, truth and beauty,
These are God - and will attest there here we rest

l.add: Secure, though weak: for these attest

lg.l: That must be self-consuming -
A bale-fire Final Good illuming: -
All then - all is for the best!
But no man should less active be,
Believing thus, - as not less free
To use his strength, skill, wit, to reach
The things attractive unto each:
And somewhat good will ever run
From all that's well designed and done,
Though out beyond our range it go,
(Because by God's hand prospered so)
Or wide of what we aimed at - test
All should not be for the best.

div.head:
A Political Gospel. not copied in manuscript
W.H

lg.l: The world's heart is kindless and grey and unholy
As the head of the Wandering Jew,
And can never be won from the curse of its folly
Till Man to Humanity's true!
There's a path to redemption - but that shall we miss,
Till we seek it no more in the old warring manner,
But are ready to fight a new battle with this
Brave motto inscribed on our banner:
To principles let us be loyal alway,
And true to all good in Man's general story;
Not to that trumpery cheatery - Royal Display!
And that blood-drinking Juggernaut - National Glory!
And though ever some one, to be doughty and noted,
Like Nimrod, should aim at a throne,
It were easy to leave him, a wight self-devoted,
To brood o'er his project alone!
Or
Or to meet him at once with a withering hiss
From hearts out of love with ambition's old manner,
And fired for a new race of glory with this
Brave motto inscribed on their banner:
To principles let us be loyal alway,
And true to all good in Man's general story;
Not to that trumpery - Royal Display!
And that blood-drinking Juggernaut - National Glory!
I dreamt my little boy were dead,
And I was sitting wild and lone;
On closed unmoving knees my head
Lay rigid as a stone.
And there thus I sat without a tear,
And though I drew life's painful breath,
All life to me seemed cold and drear,
And comfortless as death:
Sat on the Earth as on a bier
Where Loss and Ruin lived alone,
Without the comfort of a tear -
Without a passing groan.
And there was stillness everywhere
Insphering one wide sense of woe:
The stillness of a world's despair
Whose tides had ceased to flow.
Yea, so eternal seemed my grief,
Time moved not, neither slow nor fast,
Nor recked I whether periods brief
Or centuries had passed.
It was as if to marble cold
My loss had petrified the air,
And I was shut within its hold,
Made deathless by dispair.
Made deathless in a world of death,
There ever sitting wild and lone,
With all but one pent painful breath
Transmuted into stone!
And
And more the gorgon horror crushed
With dry petrific pressure in,
Till forth my waking spirit rushed
With agonising din!
And oh! what joy it was to wake -
To cast that haggard dream away,
And from its stony influence break
Into the living day!
I sought the objects of my care,
And felt, while I embraced the train,
How much even from a dream's despair
A Father's love may gain.

div.head: A King in Vain * Finally copied

lg.l: Still his little grave she seeketh
In her mother-sorrow wild!
Hush! while in her heart she speaketh
To the spirit of her child:

l.add: "Oh,

lg.l: "Oh! were we not to one another
Once the sum of all sweet gain?
Say then; - say unto thy Mother,
Shall we ever meet again?
Darling! shall we meet again,
Knowing, loving one another?"
Nothing but the wind is heard
Sighing in reply,
Where the long grave-grass is stirred
As it passeth by.
"Ah! what weary, weary sorrows
Have I known through loss of thee!
And what comfortless to-morrows
Wait me in this misery!
And were we not to one another
Once the sum of all sweet gain?
Say then; - say unto thy Mother,
Shall we ever meet again?
Darling! shall we meet again,
Knowing, loving one another?"
Still
Still the wind alone is heard
Sighing in reply,
Where the long grave-grass is stirred
As it passeth by.

div.head:
All is for the Best.
Love, Friendship and Faith. *

lg.l: What so sweet upon the earth
As young Love's honey dew? love, when it is new
Or what so wealthy priceless in its worth,
If Love were only true?
What like Friendship for a shield
'Gainst want and riches too?
Or what such summer fruit might yield,
If Friendship were but true?
What like Faith, whose vision brings
The gates of heaven in view,
With Love and Friendship for its wings,
If all alike were true?
All alike of trusty stuff -
And why are they not so?
There surily still were room - age room enough
For misery here below.
When heaven is waxing grey, Mary,
The dawning isles between,
And the stars are paling fast away
In Morning's brighter sheen:
While the broad red sun is breaking then
From out the burning sea,
All life to gladness waking - then
My spirit longs for thee.
And when, in noontide strength, Mary,
He bares his flaming blades,
Till Nature's busy tribes at length
Lie panting in the shades:
While the sea, like white fire glowing then,
Though cool and fresh it be,
Is
Is only heard far flowing - then
I'm lonely without thee.
When clouds in crimson dyed, Mary,
Bedrape heaven's western gate,
Till like a rare and royal bride
Eve enters there in state:
While yon cliff-born kids all prancing then,
Are mirrored in the sea,
In its wide joy out glancing - then
I love to think of thee.
And when Night's throned again, Mary,
And all the stars are met
To sing their old creation-strain
Eve Hespers be set:
While the silver moon is beaming then,
And in the silent sea,
Her other Self in dreaming - then
My heart is full of thee.
A Man of Sorrows and with grief acquainted,
He bowed his beauteous head to the rude hands
Of Pilate's hireling bands;
And while beneath their cruel scourge he fainted,
Forgave them, - yearning through his shameful smart
Even with a Brother's heart.
And when upon the infamous Cross they nailed him,
With hatred's mockery and scorn's bitter smile,
Hark , how he prayed, the while
Nature's extremest agony assailed him,
"Father! thy mercy even for these renew;
They know not what they do."
And why, thus wronged, did he in spirit trample
Such natural indignation down, as now
Pain, , while we read, , our brow?
That Love, sublimed by his divine example,
Might reach , and thence convert , that hate in men
Which crucified it then.
'Tis long ago - but oft, even yet,
The death-calm visage of a Child
Comes shrouded from the past, to re-beget
An ancient sorrow wild!
The face of him - our gentle-eyed
Henry, - the little One Boy One that died.
I heard an outcry in the night
And then a deep sad voice, that said
'Tis even so; my boding heart was right -
Our poor sick Boy is dead!
And yet my sense of loss but seemed
Like some vague wild thing I had dreamed.

l.add: For the great precept of his Christianity
Was always - 'Be in charity - yea, live
To love and to forgive;
That so my spirit may through all humanity
Pass ever downward with a widering birth,
Till Peace possess the earth.

lg.l: But when that solemn night was passed,
The feeling of how wide a sea
Had in the ghostly darkness rolled its vast
Black depth 'twixt him and me,
Even as I breathed it, damped the air
With life's first terrible despair!
I
I sought a lonely spot, and lay
Prone on the ground for very woe!
And what (O God!) if my wild grief that day
Did in its wildness show
That we, on Time's change-beaten shore
Had parted - never to meet more!
But no! that cannot - cannot be!
In soul we yet must meet again -
This love, my Brother, mourning yet for thee,
Can ask it not in vain;
Nor Heaven design a rent more fell
Than were reunion though in Hell!

div.head:
The Night Bird. Finally copied
not in manuscript
W.H

lg.l: To cheer my lonely dwelling shed,
Upon its humble roof is heard,
As duly I retire to bed,
A little nightly Bird:
Hark! ever there the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
Beneath the silent shining stars,
Or while the moon pays down her light,
Although no wiery thraldom bars
The freedom of its flight,
There nightly thus it ever sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And while I listen, there will come
Dim memories of the Past, that say
Upon my Childhood's happy home
A little shrilling lay
Was nightly heard, like this that brings
Those iterant but melodious things.
I know not if it was in kind
The same with yon peculiar bird,
But on my Father's roof I mind
How often we had heard
A voice like this without, that sings
Those iterant but melodious things.
But where is he, the parent sage
Whose Seven then met his nightly call?
And he, whose cheek of tenderest age
Was fondliest kissed of all?
My heart asks - while the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And now too there's a Grave new made
'Mid scenes to memory unknown,
And there cold stranger hands have laid
Our manly-hearted John!
I weep - while still the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
Flowers in their freshness are flushing the earth,
And the voice-peopled forest is loud in its mirth,
And stream in their fulness are laughing at dearth,
Yet my bosom is aching.
There's shadow on all things - the shadow of wo;
It falls from my spirit wherever I go,
As from a dark cloud drifting heavy and slow low;
For my spirit is weary.
If I ask of my heart, why is it not cheery?
If I ask of my spirit, why is it so weary?
Hark, from the depths of a dead love how drearly
Wails the answer of Sorrow!
Wails from those dead depths, so darkling and lonely,
To where in the lap of Despair I have thrown me,
Though by my listening spirit heard only -
That wild answer of Sorrow:
"What can be flowers in their freshness to thee,
Or the glad voices that people the green forest tree,
Or the full joy of streams - since thy soul sighs, Ah me!
O'er the grave of thy Mary?"
Under the glad blithe face of Nature, her face
Hath carried down with it all beauty and grace!
Pale lies is it there, in that dark silent peace -
Mary! O Mary!
Pale
Pale comes the wraith of it home to my heart,
Comes through the feeling that will not depart,
Of how once it could smile me to peace - and I start,
Stung through with keen anguish!
Stung as if living to anguish alone;
Wild for a moment; - then cold as the stone
At the head of thy grave, do I stand there, and groan
Mary! O Mary!
Who that had been in the days of his youth
Won by thy beauty and blest by thy truth,
Would live in a world where nor anguish nor ruth
May avail the bereaved one?
Fierce glares that thought, like a flash in the night
When a tempest is rushing from Mindelow's height,
And never may any less terrible light
Illumine my sorrow!
Children are by me - her children! O God!
To see where their feet have unwittingly trod
Tiny tracks in the loam of the new broken sod
Betwixt them and their Mother!
'Twixt them and the true One who loved us in truth!
Who bore them - to die 'mid the hopes of her youth!
Who would live in a world where nor anguish nor ruth
May avail the bereaved Ones?
Yet must I live, lest her spirit showed say,
Meeting mine in its flight from this of clay, wild world away
"Where are our little ones? Where do they stay?
And why did you leave them?
"Dying I thought of the loss they would rue
In their Mother, and dire was the pang that it drew,
And who was then left to brood o'er them but you?
Ah! why did you leave them?"
If for them only then, so must it be!
See I remain with them, Mary! - but see
How lonely we stand in a world without thee!
Mary! O Mary!
I live - but Death's shadow in over me cast:
And even when weary Woe sleepeth at last,
Some dream of the dead, sighing out of the past,
Is alive in the darkness!
How can my heart then be ever more cheery?
How can my spirit be other than weary?
Hark, from some dead depth of being how drearly
Sorrow waileth her answer!
Wails from that dead depth, so darkling and lonely,
To where in the lap of Despair I have thrown me,
Though by my listening spirit heard only -
That wild answer of Sorrow!
Could I but weep, it were comfort, though brief;
But the fountain of tears by the fire of my grief
Hath been dried to its dregs, and can shed no relief
On the thirst of my eyelids!
As music that wasteth away on the blast,
As the last ray by the sunken sun cast,
All my heart's gladness hath died in the past!
Mary! O Mary!
Heard by my spirit alone: while it makes
Its listening silence so felt that it aches,
Till with a mystical shudder it
At the thought of our children

div.head:
x
A Summer Night Scene.
not in manuscripts
W.H

lg.l: Let us go forth: for beautiful is the night!
Most beautiful! The wide fields deep in maize,
And orchard-bosomed homes, and, zoning all,
The old and solemn woods
Float in a silver sea,
Poured from the fountains of the rising Moon,
Who, half behind yon hill-top, seemeth there
A casque of figured gold
On Earth's uplifted head.

l.add: [Hertha's lifted head]

lg.l: Heaven's sparkling companies have clustered out
To hail their coming Queen, and interweave
Their fervent peans with her milder strain;
But over all beneath
Reigns Silence, - undisturbed
Save when, at solemn intervals, there hangs
Within the viewless tresses of the breeze,
Some accent of the brook
Quick glittering from afar.

div.head: An Aboriginal Mother's Lament. Finally Copied

div.p:
[It will be rememebered that, not a great many about twenty years years
back, a party of Stockmen (several of whom were afterwards
executed for the crime) made wholesale slaughter of a
small tribe of defenceless Blacks - to the number, it is
believed, of more than a score - heaping their bodies,
as they slaughtered them like cattle, upon a large fire
kindled for the purpose. Of this doomed tribe, one
woman only, with her infant, as it appeared subsequently
upon evidence, escaped the Whiteman's vengeance.
And this Poem is supposed to describe the ejaculations
of the Mother, after she has fled to a considerable
distance from the scene of the massacre, and when
wearied and overtaken by the night.]

lg.l: Yet farther would I fly, my Child,
To make the safer yet
From the Whiteman's so unsparing
Dread hand, all murder-wet!
Yet bear the on as I have borne
With stealthy strides so fleet,
But the dark shuts up the Forest
And thorns are in my feet!
O moan not! - I would give this braid
That once bound Hibbi's brow,
Were it but for a single palmful
Of water for the now.
Ah spring not to his name; - no more
To glad us may he come;
He is smouldering into ashes
Beneath the blasted gum:
All chanced and blasted by the fire
The Whiteman kindled there,
And fed with our slaughtered kindred
Till heaven-high went its glare!
O moan not! &c
And but for thee, I would their fire
Had eaten me as fast!
Hark! hark! do I hear his death cry
Yet lengthening up the blast?
But no - when his bound hands had signed
The way that we should fly,

l.add: On

lg.l: On the roaring pyre flung bleeding,
I saw thy Father die!
O moan not! &c
No more shall his loud tomahawk
Be plied for our relief,
Or the shining fish-pools darken
Beneath their shadowing Chief!
The fading track of his fleet foot
Shall guide not as before,
And the mountain Spirits mimic
His hunting call no more!
O moan not! - I would give this braid
Thy Father's gift to me,
Were it but for a single palmful
Of water now for thee!

div.head: ode The Hand of God. Finally copied

lg.l: Where with a philosophic quest
Creation is surveyed,
The Hand of God must be confest
In all that he hath made.
We see it though the subtlest simplest means
Attaining subtlest ends,
Where nothing wrongly supervenes,
And nothing vainly tends.
We see it, - dimly, it may be,
But there it is - the line
That ever points to unity
In manifold design.
As when a living leaf we place
Between us and the sun,
All through it, with a vein-like trace,
The life is seen to run:
Seen ribbing from one central spine

l.add: In modes so surely fit,
As still to be, through every line
In final union

lg.l: Yea,
Yea, thus, when with a heedful quest
Creation is surveyed,
The Hand of God must be confest
In all that he hath made.
A Streamlet is a bright and beauteous creature
In some wide desert , where it keeps a part
Of each wayfarer's heart;
The Star of Evening is a gracious feature,
Instinct as 'twere with all the love that eyes
Have looked through at the skies.
And hence one emblems in its beauteous being,
The memory of a love that in our heart
Flowed gratefully apart;
The other to our spiritual seeing,
The perpetuity of that love's white grace
Yet in some heavenly place.

div.head: The Widow's Dying Boy. Final Copy

lg.l: "I do not fear to die, mother, -
Why should I fear to die,
Since God hath many a better world
Away in the starry sky?
But thinking of the how the Past, that hath left
Its sunsets in my heart,
And of all With all thy loving motherhood,
I weep that we must part.
"It is leaving you alone, mother,
With little sister Bell,
Whom we both love so tenderly,
And who loveth us so well;
I'm thinking of a thousand things
That we have done in play, -
And how lonely will poor Bell be
When I am reft away!
"And who will bring you chips, mother,
And water from the well?
And who - for 'tis a lonely way -
Will go to school with Bell?
I know 'tis sinful to repine -
'Tis good to be resigned;
Yet sorrow is in the thought of how
I'm leaving you behind.
Nor can I well forego, mother,
The fondly cherished plan
Of all I had to do for you
When once I were a man:
Ah, this, that erst in prospect touched
The world with summer bloom,
Hath shrunk into a withered waste withered down to a cold grey waste
Between me and out beyond the tomb!
But when the flowers are growing, mother,
About the little mound
That near my Father's larger grave
Shall ridge the churchyard ground,
Go you not there for sorrow then
But down on the grassy sod
To kneel, and pray (as I've heard you oft)
A mother's prayer to God.
Hark! hear yon that sweet music, mother,
That breathes as from afar?
And see you yonder heavenly light
Outshining like a star?
Its bright haze wraps me, and there falls
An Image o'er my brain -
I wander - for it seemed my sire
Was here with us again.
Give me your hand to feel, mother,
My sight is failing fast;
And kiss me again - and yet again,
For all the faithful Past." -
Then in the calm of the perfect love,
As silently he lay,
Her gentle-hearted Boy looked up -
Looked - smiled - and passed away.
She mourns, and will not be consoled
And yet the widowed one
A fortunate mother must I hold
Who mourns for such a son:
For God, whose mercy never bruised
A spirit but to heal it,
If Love were mortal, ne'er had used
Mortality to feel it.
That soul-felt life within the Past
Which living love engenders;
That kindred pulse which is the last
The dying heart surrenders;
Do give our thoughts assurance sweet
The more their ends we trace,
That pasting here is but we only part to meet
In some supernal place.
Nay For, were the truth not herein said,
Even Love were oft a curse,
Since if we had cherished Hate instead
It hardly at had bruised us worse!
But God is love, - and hence its power
The life of Man doth leaven,
To gift its frailty with a flower
Whose final fruits is in is Heaven.
A Trooper of France, in desperate need,
Had struggled from under his dying steed
Where Egypt's pyramid's appeared
In giant brick, as if giant-reared;
While on his black war-horse, the Turk
Who had borne his down, to finish his work
Back wheelingly careered.

l.add: Wheeled back, and at him again careered

lg.l: Taking his resolute stand
Foot-deep in his Charger's blood,
The soldier of Christendom sword in hand
(A trusty blade and good,
That glared as it moved, like the lightning tongue
Of a settling cloud that had just been flung
By the rending rush of a wheelblast, far
Out in the front of the storm of War)
His foe awaiting stood.
Urged into uttermost speed,
On - on with a scattering tail,
Like the hurrying thunder-bolt's smoky trail!
On - on with a streaming main,
Like the foremost tracks of a hurricane!
On came the Tartar steed.
Then passed, with a vengeful clash
Of shivering blades, and a sludgy splash,
And lastly a lunging downward crash,
The imminent shock!
And when its cloud of dust upthrown
Cleared off, there stood that Trooper alone,
Firm as stands the topmost stone
Of a midsea rock,
Over which, all in vain, a black Storm had just blown!
But two steeds and a Moslem in death lay still -
And a kite of the that came with a flop
In heavy flight from a pyramid's top,
In a hunger-glad mood
At the scent of blood,
Was circling oer over and screaming shrill -
Screaming with hunger, and screaming for joy
As she thought of her famishing brood,
For that Man the destroyer so well could destroy
And glut them so bravely with food.

div.head:
Finally copied Yearnings. not copied in manuscripts
W.H

lg.l: "Ah, that yon Moon, when thus silverly beaming,
Might some through the spills of my passionate dreaming,
In the guise of a lady fair, blessing and blest,
And pillow my head on her beautiful breast!
"Ah, that yon star which in heaven is whitest,
Might come when Love's visions around me are brightest, -
Like a fancy-pale God Maiden dream-drawn from her rest, -
And rap me away to its home in the West!
"Ah, that the Spirit of music by flowing,
When Love, the pure test of all beauty, is glowing,
Might take such a shape as my heart can conceive,
And breathe in my arms like a daughter of Eve!
"Ah, that some snowy-wing'd Angel of heaven,
But once to the sight of my spirit were given,
So rich in the beauty born with on high,
That to love her were death - I would love her and die!"
Thus sang a Poet Boy wandering lonely
Whilst yet he had tasted life through his dreams only:
Born deep into beauty, of beauty he dreamed
As the soul queen of all being - how vanity it seemed!
For the Moon with pale love of the day-god was beaming,
And the Star of some star that attracts her was dreaming,
And the Music remained an invisible birth,
And no Daughter of bliss might descend to the earth!
Yet not all vainly her spirit was burning
Tow'rds the rare and the deathless; - the fruits of its yearning
Had blossom in Eden, nor can shall they be hurled
Away with the perishing weeds of the world.

div.head:
not in manuscripts
W.H A Man Shall be a Man yet.

lg.l: Then It must be in Man's fortunes,
Sinced the Sire of man is God,
That a better ruler's coming
Than grim Force with iron rod;
And to make our faith the firmer,
There is, even now, a great
And growing brotherhood of men
Vow'd to that better state:
And whose standard is that standard
'Neath whose broad folds unfurled
A man shall be a man yet
All over the world.
First Oh!, then , away for ever
With all unfraternal hate -
All envyings 'twixt the rich and poor,
The little and the great!
And be we of that noble
And for ever - growing band,
Whose worship is the Just and True
Alike in every land:

l.add: And, high or low, united,
Hero-hand in hero-hand,
Best show we how the Truth at last
Must reign o'er every Land:
And what standard &c

lg.l: And whose standard is that standard
'Neath whose broad folds unfurled,
A man shall be a man yet
All over the world.
But down with all down pullers -
All mere haters of command!
Since For who bows not to what's noble
And thence glorious in the land,
Can
Can never be one in spirit
With that fraternisinghearted host,
Which yet, in God's good time, is doomed
To rule the social roast:
And whose standard is that standard
'Neath whose broad folds unfurled,
A man shall be a man yet
All over the world.
Down too with all mere brawlers
At what luxury they see,
Since 'tis well to roll in riches
If but fairly won they be -
Well to shine amongst our fellows,
Though the thorough man alone
Is one who through his golden heart,
And not his gold, is known:
And whose standard is that standard
'Neath whose broad flag folds unfurled,
A man shall be a man yet
All over the world.

div.head: Advertisement.
div.p:
What the reading - or rather, the poetical
Public may think of the following Lyrical
Love Story, I know not. But for
myself I know, that we have not, in
our Language, any thing much better of
its kind; and that it has also, apart
from its merely poetic merit, a metaphysical
value, that will be very gratifying to all
those readers who may have the grace to
perceive it.

div.head:
Finally copied
I would get me a New Love.

lg.l: I would get me a new love,
The old fire is out!
I would get me a new love
Ere Spring comes about!
That as in her warm arms
The fields all re-bloom,
My love heart may awaken
From coldness and gloom.
O there's nothing in nature
Like love when 'tis new;
And there's nothing in fortune
Like love when 'tis true!
But my passion for Meg, was
A fire that's gone out;
And I'd get me a new love
Ere Spring comes about.
I would get me a new love,
Less Custom's cold slave;
And I'd get me a new love
More earnest and brave!
Too pure to mistrust me,
Too noble to doubt!
I would get such a new love
Ere Spring comes about.
But if such a new love
I no where might may get,
I'd as lief be thus lonely -
Nay, lonelier yet!
Than have one like the old love,
Just playing a part,
With a flare in her fancy,
But ice at her heart.
O wert thou mine, beloved Girl!
How rich I were with such a mate,
Abject around me still should whirl
The most injurious waves of Fate!
No more disgust, no more despair
Should snake-like coil about my life!
So couldst thou bless me, didst thou dare
To be a Poet's Wife.
Before us see how frets the sea
Of life, at best a changeful state!
And think ere thou putt'st forth with me
Where heart alone can cope with Fate,
How many new and clinging cares,
World-born to an unworldly life,
Must be her crown of thorns, who dares
To be a Poet's Wife!
A spirit gentle and resigned
Must speak her boundless faith in love,
And in the temper of her mind
The lioness obey the dove:
A heart above mere fortune's snares,
And all the petty pride of life -
These must be her rich dower, who dares
To be a Poet's Wife!
And these are thine, beloved One!
And I, since thou wilt be my secure of such a mate,
Believe that Love's full risen sun
Can fill with light the dark of Fate;
And that all needful toil and care
Shall breathe for me this psalm of life:
Dare all for her who all could dare -
A destined Poet's Wife.
Beware Child, in your gambols,
Of the fatal rift below: -
Thus did a Switzer warn his Boy,

A roseate color; from her moistening lips
Low murmers too had broken: whereupon
My parents, in the exultant hope of still
Consummating their bargain, had transformed
The fancial to a general tribal feast
And loaded me with all the family gauds
And ornaments they held. The Persian too
Had been inverted to renew his purchase
And carry me at once beyond the chance
Of future opium doses
With the rest
Back had he galloped, and was now without,
Eager once more to bear me to the arms
Of his long- Lord. Within he came
In wonder, but full ready to make good
His former bargain and pay down the gold prier
My worthy parents tenderly embraced me,
With many tears, protesting that I was
The life light of their eyes - their rose of Joy!
Then stretched their palms out for the Persian gold,
And hurried off to tell it oer in secret:
The dear recovered treasure they so late
Had mourned, as lost for ever. On that night
I was packed carefully on a camel's back
Beside a case of porcelain pipes and gini-cracks
And carried Persia-ward, by stages long
From the Circussian mountains.
At the court
I soon became the favorite of the king;
Lived sumptuously, but in perpetual fear.
My food was served to me on plates of gold
I slept on beds the furniture of which
Were fringed with countless pearls; and yet no less
I envied the poor slave who swept the floors
My Persian Lord for one whole month had been
Devoted to me - for a month and more:
And then I heard my place was to be filled
By a new favorite. And strange to say,
Albeit I loathed him as we loathe a snake,
I could not bear that he should thus supply
My presence with another. I would make
An effort to regain his faded favor:
For I was beautiful - and therefore vain
As beauty needs must be. And to that end
I now arrayed myself in robes that seemed
Aeriel ultimates of perfect whiteness,
While scarfs of purple such as only queen's
May purchase from the Indus Caravans,
Barred them with rainbow tints; a burnished band
Of purest gold, whose midst throughout was raised
With a full row of pearls - all perfect ovals -
Held in the wavelets of my sunny hair:
A gem that seemed indeed a frozen mass
Of white fire, flashed upon my silk-soft brow.
And Then in my loveliness, even thus arrayed,
I swam into his presence (though indeed
My hid feet rowed me) graceful as a swan!
The Harem girls applauded, while thus seemed
Even in his own dull eyes almost a flash
As of exhorted joy: but which became
At the next moment a malignant scowl,
Which had its dark source in such thoughts as these:
(As from a Nubean girl after I learned after from a Nubean girl
Who always waited in his baser needs)
"What! did a soft and egriorant minx like me
Think to entrap again a man like him,
Who was the sharpest fellow, past all doubt,
In all the orient? Did a minx so raw
Think Ween to outwit a piece of such intelligence,
By floating in before him, like a swan,
A little better feathered than at first?"
Even while this mischief had been mustering up,
The Harem ladies had been all been dismissed,
The Nubean girl alone remaining; then
A conclave of those singular gnome-like things dwarfs

Was to be poisoned - and with a pomegranate,
One of a number to be pluckt and brought
For every lady of his Harem, forth
At supper, from his favorite Summer Garden trees,
And one too for himself, though he disliked them.
The Nubean had slipped away and told me
All she had learned: yet her news moved me not,
So sure I felt that such was not my doom;
Or moved me but to this - the packing up

But time slid on, and we were summoned forth
To supper. On the centre board of a crate there stood
Of silver crate piled high with crimson goards
And these the king despersed amongst us soon,
To every lady one; till two at last
Alone remained, one of them being marked.
This came to me, nor could I but accept it,

And flurried all the ladies, till they thronged
About me - flurried even the king himself.
With infinite dexterity I then
Revived as suddenly, and contrived the while
Amid the bustle to exchange the goards -
Took his, and left him mine. His soon I ate
And praised as being the very soul of fruit.
He also with a rollic in his eye
Ate that which had been poisoned, and avowed
He never knew before what fruit it was,
Nay, that it held within its crimson rind
The juice of Paradise.
While this went on
I had slipped away wholly unseen to where
My goods were packed, and to prepare for flight.
Nor had I long withdrawn, ere to my chamber
The Nubean girl came running; telling me
That soon the king had with a monstrous snort
Fall'n prostrate; while the ladies all away
Had scattered like a flock of gossamer clouds
