lg.l: And that the chamber now was thronged instead,
To suffocation, with musty fusty mass
Of bare-poled hakims and grey-haired Physicians,
Who all concurred at least in this - the dark
Affair in hand was quite unlooked for - quite,
And had strong symptoms of a "poison-case"
And as she told her news the Nubean laughed
With infinite delight - so loved are kings!
And I laughed also, feeling that I had
A natural and a perfect night to do so.
But no time might be wasted - and we fled
Together, loaded both with costly spoils.
Still as we passed beneath the latticed Court
Wherein the Monarch suffered, all in vain
I strove to dash my womanly desire
To have a last look at him. So aloft
I mounted, on the slave's bent back - and looked.
The king was sprawling on the pillowy floor,
With quite a herd of anxious quacks about him;
Jews & Armenians, infidels and slaves,
All ranks, all races; and as still he took
Their nostrums, with grimaces horrible,
He still kept threatening them, that if they failed
To cure him ere that dreadful night were past,
The dawn should see them headless - every man!
Then would he curse the whim that made him choose wonder, why he ever chose
Pomegranates for his supper. Then in rage
He cursed his blunder, and the palpable trick
By which a silly woman had o'er reached him!
Then would he sprawl, and bellow like a beast!
And so I left him sprawling, while the sound
Of his brute ragings followed us beyond
The Garden bounds as through the dark we fled!
- We heard long after, that he died ere he
Had time to cut off all the doctor's heads.
With a strong spirit of mischied in my head,
I was not bad at heart; for those they who knew
Me closely, and the closlier they knew me
Though they saw thus, - and not the less perhaps,
If of the women sort, because 'twas plain
My conduct most was from its balance thrown
By wherein, and by human almost mad , -
These always, and the closlier they knew me,
Loved me - nay, served as the Nubian did.
And now as no one else might sell me - lo,
I sold myself, and thought that I had made
A capital bargain, till I found myself
Throned as the wife of a rude Afric Chief,
Black as a log of ebony, and who
As still at stated times, in motley state,
On bow-bent shanks and huge big pot-bellied bulk,
He strode before us, bore I must confess
Much brother likeness to a huge baboon
But luckily the monster soon preferred
The Nubian to myself - a consummation
That filled me with much thankfulness of heart
'Twere long to tell whay haps befell me next:
I was the capture of a Bedoine ab shiek
And fed his camels, while I served his lusts;
Was sold in the slave mart of Astrachan
And carried thence beyond the Ganges, where
A Rajahpoot received me as his queen.
A Turcoman horse stealer owned me next,
At once his water-carrier and his wife.
At Constantinople I became the slave
Of a harsh Roman matron, who was wont
To flog and famish me to make me good;
And when I owned myself converted, then
She flogged and famished one the more to make
My goodness lasting. But this much of change
In the contexture of my fatal past
But troubles and distracts me. The extreme
Is what I best remember: I was now
A queen; and now a drudge: and finally
Fell stabbed in Cairo - slaughtered by a slave.

div.head:
The 'Nevers of Poetry. not in manuscrips
W.H

lg.l: Never say aught in verse, or grave or gay,
That you in prose would be ashamed to say,
Or let your head in lofty numbers tell
What in your heart you deem but fit for doggerel.
Never in rhyme pretend to tears, unless
True feeling sheds them in unfeigned distress; (1.)
Or some dream-grief, with such a mournful strain
As night winds have in pine woods, stirs your brain,
To shake them, dew-like, o'er the flowers that bloom
In the wild dark round Joy's imagined tomb;
Or save when doubts that over Love may lour
Like summer clouds, break in a sunny shower
Out of your gladdened eyes, to freshen all
The bowers of memory with their grateful fall.
Never laugh either in Song's measured tone
If all the wit is in the laugh alone,
Or all the humor in a "ha-ha-ha"
That should clink (very sheepishly) with "baa".
Never write madly, as if nimble wits,
Like Arabs, showed best in their wandering fits.
Though Song has oft some beauty most divine,
Which well we feel yet cannot well define -
Some yearning excellence, intense and far,
Coming and going like a clouded star -
Some awful glory we but half descry,
Like a strong sunset in a stormy sky;
Yet ne'er be murky of set purpose, since
You only thereby may shall the more evince,
* That How even the sublime is only but then made sure,
When, like a morning alp, it breaks from the obscure: (2.)
For though it blind awhile our dazzled sight,
There's no real darkness in excessive exceeding light.
Yet never dread the kingliest critic's ire
So long as genius, like a bride of fire,
Lies glowing on thy breast, to mission and inspire;
For though thy moods to most be caviare,
They should have voice, or genius were not there.
But never sing of aught (even though in love)
That is not worth some solid thinking of.
Never heed whether a line strictly goes
By learned rule, if, - brook like, - it warble as it flows;
Or if, in concord with the thought, it fills
Fast forward, like a torrent fast flooding from the hills.
Never write slip-slop - never, I would say,
If you can help it: only asses bray!
(Though through a miserable juggle, which
Makes pricking Criticism's fury digits itch nuckles itch!)
And sure 'tis but the an assinine sublime
That's best evolved through a jog-trot of rhyme,
Or lines, like whinnies, harsh, and ending short,
Doleful and wheezy, in a kind of snort!
And never, if you would be very terse,
Be very metaphysical in verse.
Never transform in the wild view of Poe
The rote "Poor Jacko" of some stray pet crow,
(Not even with the warranty of fiction)
Into a strange blue-devilish prediction. (3.)
Never, like Halloran, mistake your "granny,"
Though shawled and bonnetted, for some blooming "Annie";
For though you aim at complimenting merely
The old girl - yet, the young girl's handled queerly! (4.)
Or say that aught is "fading like a star"
Because its glory seems to pale afar,
Since stars do not fade, but shine on no less
Though unbeheld through our weaksightedness;
And since a true trope should not rest on fancy,
But claim a universal relevancy. (5.)
Never in Fowler's Shelley-mocking strain,
Turn a rich sunset into a red rain
Cold-drenching some poor-devil Poet's brain;
Or in the wildest of your similes
Make birds to "hive - whate'er you do with bees; (6.)
Or with him think the musical in style
Is best achieved through piggled metres vile, (7.)
Or that a line is racy to the core,
And bold, and truly bravely eloquent, the more
Is striving seems to tear itself asunder,
Like this "Down there, i' the deep heart o' the thunder": (8.)
But for which, surely, (out of Chaos) none
Might feign to find a sanction - save in fun!
Never from rhyming turn, like rhymster Ray,
The ball-room Ercildoune of Botany Bay, (9.)
To ape Macenas - but in fact to be
Man-midwife to all pauper poetry;
Lest some Prout Hill with a be-grudgeoned look,
Sin-charge you with his dreadful "little booke", (10.)
Or some sad shepherd, having tailed his sheep,
Damn rhyme and you ere he in peace can sleep. (12.)
* Never with plundered imagery make
A Paphian medley, - as if one should take
Filched jewels of all sorts, and think to run
Their several special values into one
More special still; but which, when thus re-cast,
Yield but a Trinket-Frankenstien at last;
Then call (the more its spurious kind to prove)
And certes, it might "vex a saint", to think
How he was egged so nearly o'er the brink
Of hungry Scribbledom - and eke the
In wasted time and stead, wages lost!
Of hungry Bookdom! - and how much it cost
The impious miscreation "Life and Love"! (12.)
Never think harshness the best foil to raise
And relish sweetness: few love craggy lays!
Yet never be you glib, when Passion's force
Should ridge your style, - as by a tempest hoarse
The deep is roughened into waves that roar
At heaven, up-heaving, huddling, more and more,
Until To burst at last they burst in booming thunder on the shore!
Never be such a Pagan as to deem
That truth or beauty must diviner seem
For some deformity, grotesquely rude,
Prowling for evil in its neighborhood,
If such deformity breathe not the air
Of nature - being found, not conjured there.
And never to be graceless be you fain
Till to be graceful you have tried in vain.
Never be cheated - never may you be -
Into the cramp belief, that Poetry
Must of necessity in soul be one
With the mere form of verse, if it but deftly run,
Or pour, as with a mill-wheel's vigorous cheer,
A rhyming clatter hard upon the ear. (13.)
Never believe that verse a license knows
For aught that would be balderdash in prose;
Or that all reason may at any time
Find a sufficient substitute in rhyme;
Or that because with many words you're fraught
There must be under them some flood of thought.
Never pay for clinks, however ringing,
With all the meaning of the song your singing,
Lest the too-knowing reader reckon drily
The cost, and vow you bargained them vilely.
Never set one rhymes (like a rat traps) baited rhymes to clutch;

lg.l: And never, like a tinker shredding tin,
Forecut your metal, and then hammer in
As much of sense and metre as you may,
Calling what comes on't - a Pindaric lay.
Never compel a simile that won't
Take service without forcing; - if it don't
As of itself, into your poem flow,
Be true to liberty , and let it go.
Never inflate an image; - if it will
Not suit you without straining, all your skill
Shall make this but the more apparant still.
Never, with your poetic stylus, goad
Slow thoughts or feelings; they but overload
The jaded Muse, and have a hatred strong
'Gainst ever being goaded into song;
And what is sadder - and of this beware -
There hate is certain death to it when there.
Never reject a homely sounding phrase
That your whole meaning earnestly displays,
For one made current by some courtly wit
Which only barely indicates some a shade of it,
Or like the infusion of an alien potion
Flattens the native spirit of the notion,
Or which, it may be, (for it so may fall)
Does not express what you would mean at all!
Never, Procrustes-like, stretch out a live
And regular battalion verse of five
Well measured feet (just to amuse the ear)
Into an Alexandrine grenadier.
Never describe a cabbage with great throes
Poetic, under the proud name of Rose;

And never let aught pass your bardic nose
As sweet in verse that would smell vile in prose. (14.)
And never Never, too, if you would be extant long,
Imitate England's newest sons of song; (15.)
Those crude, affected, pap-fed mystics, who
Rather than not sing in a manner new,
Sing horrible whimsies in a style that quite
Out-Crashaws Crashaw's, in its wildest flight!
Verse ever lax, or barbarously ornate!
Verse ever slip-shod in its metric gate gait!
And looking vastly like some splay-foot strain
Of psalmody run mad or grown prophane!
Or verse that fain would be as sweet as hony
Through fiddling iterations, quiant and funny,
And which even when melodiously it runs,
Is feeble in its flow, like Tennyson's. (16.)
And lastly, never take for gospel all
Your friends say of your genius when they call
Its merits o'er; but at the same time see
That you do never think yourself to be
So great an ass as your known foes declare
They do most solemnly believe you are.

div.head: Notes. 9.
div.p:
(1.) The pathetic in poetry (as in all fiction) is never so truly
effective as when it is perfectly unforced, both in subject and
manner. To be supremely exquisite, it must be given to flow
naturally out of the subject in hand, and not be cast about it like
a mourning cloak. Hence, whenever a poet takes up his pen
of set purpose to search our hearts to the very core, it is more than
likely, that he will only search our patience to an unpleasant degree,
or irk and disgust us with some vile and bloated mockery of sorrow. Any
undertaker can bespangle the lid of a coffin with tinsel-headed
nails: to bedrop it with tears is another matter, of which
nature, and not artifice, must be the principal getter up.

In so much does the truest pathos result from an unforced
treatment of a doleful matter, that we are always most nearly
touched by such pathetic descriptions as appear to come in
quite incidentally. There is a fine example of this in Henry
Taylor's Philip Van Artevelde. I know of no passage in any
author, more sweetly sorrowful; more holy in the moral depth
and beauty of its sadness. It is an account of the appearance
in death, of two children, who have perished of famine during
the seige of Ghent, and is spoken by Clara the sister of
the hero.

lg.l: He plucked aside the curtain of the couch,
And there two children's bodies lay composed.
They seemed like twins of some ten years of age,
And they had died so nearly both together,
He could not say which first: and being dead,

l.hi: He put them, for some fanciful affection,
Each with its arm about the other's neck;

lg.l: So that a fairer sight I had not seen
Than those two children, with their little faces

l.hi: So thin and wan, so calm, and sad, and sweet.

lg.l: I looked upon them long, and for awhile
I wished myself their sister, and to lie

l.hi: With them in death as they did with each other.

lg.l: I thought that there was nothing in the world
I could have loved so much; and then I wept.

div.p:
Again: - A pathetic effect in poetry is never more entire
than when, by the seeming absuptness of unmixed passion,
it is light, as it were, somewhat short of itself - but
suggestively so; or than when, in its means, it is brought
bluffly out, and as suddenly terminated, like a natural
crag, - upon whose rigid verge we are left hanging, in the
agony of our sympathy, as over some dim unmeasured
profound of loss unspeakable. No doubt this fulness of
effect is often thus achieved through the suggestion of Art; but
then it is true art, itself the suggestion of Nature. There is a
